entry.title: SAP Databricks: Building an Intelligent Enterprise with AI Unleashed – Part 3
entry.content:
Part 1 – SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 – Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 – Connect SAP Data Products with non-SAP data from AWS S3
Part 4 – End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 5 – Create inferences and endpoints for application integration with SAP Build

SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud 

In today's data-driven world, gaining a 360-degree view of your enterprise requires combining data from all corners of your business. SAP systems house governed business data. Meanwhile, Amazon S3 often contains unstructured or external data—everything from web logs and partner data to machine learning features and fraud detection inputs.

In this part of our blog series, we’ll walk you through connecting SAP Databricks to an Amazon S3 bucket — empowering you to unify data from diverse sources and accelerate your analytics and AI workflows.

By the end of this guide, you’ll have:

  • A Unity Catalog external location pointing to your S3 bucket
  • A registered table in Unity Catalog
  • A ready-to-run SAP Databricks notebook to analyze your unified data

We will be covering the following steps in this guide:

  • Step 1 – Create the External Location (AWS Quickstart)
  • Step 2 – Generate a Personal Access Token (PAT) in SAP Databricks
  • Step 3 – Identify (or create) the target S3 bucket
  • Step 4 – Configure the AWS IAM Role & Policies
  • Step 5 – Launch the AWS Quickstart CloudFormation Stack
  • Step 6 – Provide the PAT to the CloudFormation Stack
  • Step 7 – Verify CloudFormation Completion
  • Step 8 – Test the External Location connection in SAP Databricks
  • Step 9– Create a Unity Catalog table from the S3 data
  • Step 10 – Work with SAP Data Products and non-SAP data from S3 within the SAP Databricks Notebook environment 

Let's dive in.

Step-by-Step Playbook: Connecting AWS S3 to SAP Databricks

Prerequisites

  • You must create the S3 bucket that you want to use as an external location before you create the external location object in SAP Databricks. More details documented here:
    • The AWS CloudFormation template supports only S3 buckets.
    • The name of an S3 bucket that you want users to read from and write to cannot use dot notation (for example, incorrect.bucket.name.notation). For more bucket naming guidance, see the AWS bucket naming rules.
    • Avoid using a path in S3 that is already defined as an external location in another Unity Catalog metastore. You can safely read data in a single external S3 location from more than one metastore, but concurrent writes to the same S3 location from multiple metastores can lead to consistency issues.
  • If you don't use the AWS CloudFormation template to create the external location, you must first create a storage credential in SAP Databricks that gives access to the cloud storage location path. See the following AWS doc: Create a storage credential.

If you use the AWS CloudFormation flow, that storage credential is created for you.

Permissions requirements

  • You must have the CREATE EXTERNAL LOCATION privilege on both the metastore and the storage credential referenced in the external location. Metastore admins have CREATE EXTERNAL LOCATION on the metastore by default.
  • If you are using the AWS CloudFormation template, you must also have the CREATE STORAGE CREDENTIAL privilege on the metastore. Metastore admins have CREATE STORAGE CREDENTIAL on the metastore by default.

This guide assumes you're using the SAP Databricks Quickstart on AWS, which automates much of the setup. Advanced users may opt for a manual setup with your IAM role (ARN), including the encryption algorithm of SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS.

Step 1 – Create the External Location

  • In SAP Databricks Unity Catalog, navigate to "Create an external location".
  • Use the Quickstart wizard to create your external location.
  • Alternatively, advanced users can manually configure an AWS IAM Role and specify the S3 bucket path.

Step 2 – Generate a Personal Access Token (PAT)

  • In SAP Databricks, generate a PAT that will be used during the AWS CloudFormation setup.

Step 3 – Identify Your S3 Bucket

  • Meanwhile, choose or create the S3 bucket that holds your non-SAP data.
  • Example: Fraud detection data (AWS sample data).

Step 4 – Configure Your AWS IAM Role & Policies

Ensure the IAM role used by SAP Databricks has the following permissions to enable secure and functional access to your AWS data environment:

  • AmazonS3FullAccess
    Grants full access to all Amazon S3 buckets and objects within the account.
    Used to read/write data from S3, list buckets, and manage objects.
  • AmazonS3TablesFullAccess
    Grants access to AWS Glue tables and data lake metadata.
    Supports Unity Catalog integration with external tables stored in S3.
  • AmazonS3ObjectLambdaExecutionRolePolicy
    Enables the role to invoke AWS Lambda functions when accessing S3 objects.
    Required only if using S3 Object Lambda to dynamically transform or filter data before it is consumed by Databricks.
  • IAMFullAccess
    Grants full access to manage IAM resources such as roles, policies, users, and groups.
    Recommended only for administrative or automated setup environments (e.g., CloudFormation). For production, follow the principle of least privilege and only allow specific IAM actions such as iam:PassRole or iam:AssumeRole.

Step 5 – Launch the AWS Quickstart CloudFormation Stack

  • Launch the Quickstart template from within SAP Databricks, and it will direct you to the AWS Quickstart CloudFormation Stack.
  • Note the Personal Access Token (PAT) as you'll be prompted to input it in AWS.

Step 6 – Provide Your Personal Access Token to the Stack

  • Input the PAT generated in Step 2 to allow SAP Databricks access.

Step 7 – Verify Stack Completion

  • Monitor the CloudFormation Stack – the status will change from CREATE_IN_PROGRESS to CREATE_COMPLETE.

Step 8 – Test the External Location Connection

  • In SAP Databricks, return to your external location under Catalog Explorer and click “Test Connection”.
  • Verify permissions for Read, Write, and more.

Step 9 – Create a Unity Catalog Table from the S3 Data

  • Select a file in your S3 bucket and register it as a table in Unity Catalog.
  • Navigate to Unity Catalog to confirm your new table appears and is accessible for querying

Step 10 – Work with SAP Data Products and non-SAP S3 Data within the Notebook environment

  • Use the SAP Databricks notebook environment to run analyses on your newly unified data.
  • You can join SAP Data Products with external S3 data for richer insights, all within the same environment.

By connecting AWS S3 to SAP Databricks, you can seamlessly unify external and SAP business data for more powerful analytics and AI workflows. This integration enables easy access, management, and analysis of diverse datasets within SAP Business Data Cloud. 

In the next part, we will explore end-to-end integration between SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud, completing the unified analytics journey from data ingestion to actionable insights.

entry.title: Re: Push notifications using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Hi Vladyslav,

Thanks for your detailed message! I totally understand the confusion around SAP BTP Mobile Services and the APK build process.

Why the Mobile Services are required:

When your app uses SAP BTP Connectivity features (like authentication, push notifications, or backend integration through Mobile Services), the build and runtime processes require Mobile Services to be enabled. This is because the app depends on the Mobile Services infrastructure to handle these features securely and correctly.

Why you can’t disable Mobile Services for your current app:

If your app is configured to use Mobile Services (for example, via the SAP Mobile Services SDK or in your app descriptor), the build tools expect Mobile Services to be enabled.

The Preview App and the APK build process enforce these checks to prevent runtime errors or misconfigurations.

Hence, even when building an empty app or trying to get an APK without Mobile Services enabled, the system detects the app settings and stops the build.

How to build an APK without Mobile Services:

The simplest way is to create a new app project without enabling Mobile Services integration. Make sure your app descriptor (manifest) and any connectivity configurations do not include Mobile Services or related plugins.

Alternatively, you can remove any Mobile Services-related configuration from your existing app and its build settings, but this can be tedious if the app already relies on those features.

Summary:

Mobile Services need to be enabled if your app uses its features.

You cannot download an APK without enabling Mobile Services if your app depends on them.

To avoid this, start with a project that does not include Mobile Services from the beginning.

Hope this helps clear things up! Feel free to share your project details if you want me to help check the exact configuration.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Whitescreen after logging in Public cloud with Zebra...
entry.content:
Hello @Nihit 

Thank you for bringing this to our attention. The issue appears to be a compatibility challenge between your Zebra scanner and the SAP Enterprise Browser. Since the scanner works well in Google Chrome, it suggests that the Enterprise Browser may have limitations in handling the scanner's input events.

Verify Zebra Scanner Configuration:

  • Ensure the scanner is set to HID Keyboard Emulation mode for broader compatibility.
  • Avoid Serial/COM or USB CDC modes, as they may not be supported by the Enterprise Browser.

Review SAP Enterprise Browser Permissions:

  • Check for input restrictions in kiosk mode or other settings that may block keyboard inputs.
  • Access the Admin Console to review input device support and configuration settings.

Test Across Browsers:

  • Test the scanner in other Chromium-based browsers like Microsoft Edge to determine if the issue is specific to the SAP wrapper.

Update Zebra Firmware and Drivers:

    • Ensure the scanner’s firmware and drivers are up to date.
    • Consider using Zebra’s SDK for enhanced integration.

Escalation and Support:

    • If issues persist, submit a support ticket with SAP for Enterprise Browser-specific help.
    • Contact Zebra Technical Support for further assistance with compatibility.

Reference

  • Zebra Enterprise Browser Setup
  • Zebra Scanner Configuration Guide
  • Zebra Scanner SDK and Developer Resources
  • SAP Notes on Peripheral Device Integration (search for scanner integration notes)

Let me know if it helps

Best regards,
Chuma

entry.title: Re: we need to deactived the ForTrade/Customs label which...
